stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on the western-themed level, focusing on fixing a duel minigame, implementing and debugging swinging saloon doors, adding a dynamic hat-growing feature to an NPC, and refactoring the audio engine to allow for custom-pitched sound effects.

development_findings.summary: The Western-themed level has been tentatively named 'Grand Sand Badland'.
A significant technical challenge with the saloon doors was resolved when Kaze realized he was using the object's own facing angle for calculations instead of the angle relative to Mario.
development_findings.quote: It was all because I used fucking face angle instead of angle to Mario.

development_findings.summary: Kaze refactored the audio engine to support per-sound pitching, creating a system that is highly efficient by ensuring there is no performance cost unless the feature is actively being used.
development_findings.quote: Every time you program something, you want it to be free of cost. If you're not using that part of codes.

development_findings.summary: The 'Grand Sand Badland' level is approaching the N64's memory limits, forcing Kaze to be selective about adding new character models or complex features.
development_findings.quote: We kind of have an issue with this level in that we're kind of out of memory. So I don't really want to add new characters if we can prevent that.

development_findings.summary: The entire game is limited by the N64's Reality Signal Processor (RSP), a performance bottleneck that affects what can be achieved graphically. Kaze is hopeful that work by contributor Sauraen will help alleviate this.
A new gameplay feature involves a bartender Koopa whose hat grows taller each time the player collects a star in the level, serving as a visual easter egg for progress.
The game features an anti-save-state mechanism where a rapping Yoshi appears to admonish the player. The rap lyrics were written by a community member, B-Turk, and implemented by Kaze.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes that developers inserting themselves into their own games is 'cringe' and will not be doing it in this project.
context_findings.quote: I think self inserts is a little cringe. If you can't get enough of me you can keep watching my streams.

context_findings.summary: Kaze holds a personal philosophy of taking all criticism seriously and analyzing it objectively, even if he ultimately decides to disregard it.
context_findings.quote: Always look at criticism very objectively. And unemotionally.

context_findings.summary: Kaze differentiates his work from popular hacks like Star Revenge, which he feels prioritize vanilla mechanics over creating a polished, new aesthetic experience that can appeal to a broader audience.
context_findings.quote: Within the community itself, like the hardcore speedrunners, I think Star Revenge is overrated... But outside of the core community you show it to anyone who's not super familiar... they're gonna think it looks awful.

context_findings.summary: Kaze's design process is problem-driven; he prefers to create features that solve an existing design need rather than inventing a problem to fit a cool idea.
context_findings.quote: You have a solution and you're looking for a problem. But I want to implement solutions to my problems.

context_findings.summary: Kaze works at a game studio using Unreal Engine, which has influenced his PC hardware choices and provides a contrast to his N64 development work.

biobak.summary: Biobak is significantly upgrading the game's visuals, as shown by his work on a container model in Course 11, transforming it from a basic shape into a detailed, weathered asset.
biobak.quote: He just started reworking course 11 and this already looks insane... It looks like it has so much depth. I mean, it's weathered. It looks really good.

biobak.summary: Biobak provided critical feedback on Kaze's saloon doors, calling them a 'shower curtain' and suggesting they be made smaller, which Kaze implemented.
biobak.quote: So you think my saloon doors look like shit. I see. I see. I can't probably make it smaller... This is a shower curtain.

zeina.summary: Zeina is creating textures for the game, specifically mentioned in the context of signs for the Boshi duel area.
Zeina (referred to as Eiza/Aeza) collaborated with Kaze on a separate, unreleased short ROM hack that he plans to make a video about.
zeina.quote: I wish Aeza was here so I could get the permission to show our compact.

key_stories.title: The Swinging Saloon Door Problem
key_stories.summary: Kaze struggled to implement functional and aesthetically pleasing saloon doors. After team feedback led to a visual redesign, a frustrating bug with the door's rotation was finally solved by fixing a single flawed variable in the physics code.
key_stories.challenge: The saloon doors in the western level were not rotating correctly, swinging in the wrong direction when pushed or punched by Mario, and their visual design was criticized by the team.
key_stories.process: Kaze first built the doors and their swinging behavior. He struggled with the physics logic, causing them to rotate incorrectly. Biobak provided feedback that they looked bad, prompting Kaze to remodel them to be smaller. The core technical issue was resolved after a long debugging session where he discovered he was using the wrong variable for the rotation calculation.
key_stories.outcome: After receiving feedback from Biobak to make the doors smaller and less like a 'shower curtain,' Kaze eventually fixed the rotation by correcting the angle calculation in the code, resulting in a physically believable and visually improved set of doors.
key_stories.key_quote: It was all because I used fucking face angle instead of angle to Mario. I think it was. Whoops.

key_stories.title: Refactoring Audio for Boshi's Voice
key_stories.summary: To change a single character's voice, Kaze had to re-engineer a core part of the game's audio engine. He rejected an inefficient brute-force method in favor of creating an elegant, optimized system for pitching individual sounds, demonstrating his commitment to performance.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze wanted to lower the pitch of the character Boshi's voice to make him sound unique, but the game's audio engine lacked an efficient way to pitch individual sound effects.
key_stories.process: Kaze identified that his initial idea for pitching sounds was too inefficient. He then investigated the original SM64 audio code, found a better but unused method for adjusting sound frequency, and refactored it into a clean, reusable system. He then integrated this system with the dialogue box code.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze implemented a new, efficient system that allows any sound to be pitched via dialogue scripts with minimal performance impact. This not only solved the immediate problem for Boshi but also created a powerful new tool for future character sound design.
key_stories.key_quote: Every time you program something, you want it to be free of cost. If you're not using that part of codes.

open_questions.context: Kaze showed a screenshot of a container model in Course 11 that Biobak had transformed from a simple box into a highly detailed, weathered asset, expressing how impressed he was.
questions: What is your process for taking a basic level blockout from Kaze and developing its final artistic identity?
How do you and Kaze collaborate to ensure the art style is cohesive across the entire game?
Can you walk us through the techniques you used on that Course 11 container to achieve that weathered, high-depth look on N64 hardware?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned that his wife, Zeina, is creating textures for the game and that they also collaborated on a separate, smaller ROM hack.
questions: What is it like to collaborate professionally on a creative project of this scale while also being married?
How do you two navigate creative disagreements or different ideas for the project?
How do you balance your work on the game with your personal life and Kaze's streaming schedule?

open_questions.context: Kaze stated that the game is 'RSP bottlenecked' and mentioned that contributor Sauraen is working on a new version of the F3DX microcode to hopefully improve performance.
questions: Can you explain in layman's terms what being 'RSP bottlenecked' means for developing a modern game on the N64?
How do these hardware limitations force you to be creative with your design and technical solutions?
What new features or visual improvements would become possible if Sauraen's work successfully reduces that bottleneck?

open_questions.context: Kaze drew a sharp contrast between his goal of creating a 'new experience' and his view of other hacks like Star Revenge, which he feels focus more on level design for 'vanilla movement'.
questions: You said you aim to create a 'new experience.' What are the core design pillars that define that experience for you in RTYI?
What specific elements of the original Super Mario 64 did you feel were essential to keep, and which did you feel were most important to change or build upon?
How do you balance respecting the original game's feel with the desire to innovate and create something that stands on its own?

open_questions.context: Kaze implemented a feature where a rapping Yoshi appears if the player uses save states. The lyrics were written by a community member, and Kaze reviewed them on stream.
questions: What was the origin of the save-state detecting Yoshi? Was it meant as a joke, a genuine deterrent, or something else?
You involve the community in very direct ways, like crowdsourcing these rap lyrics. Why is that direct collaboration important to your process?
How do you manage the line between incorporating fun community ideas and maintaining your own creative vision for the project?
